Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, theoretical models will be developed to understand recent advances and discoveries in nuclear physics and to predict possible new ones. For collisions of nuclei with very different proton and neutron numbers at current accelerators and planned Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), the relativistic transport model based on the relativistic mean-field model will be extended to include realistic initial nuclear distributions and different mean-field potentials for protons and neutrons, and then used to study the dependence of the energy of nuclear matter on its density and proton to neutron ratio via the two-nucleon correlation functions, the production of light nuclear clusters, the relative diffusion between protons and neutrons, and the ratios of various particles. For ultrarelativistic heavy-ion collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), the strong gluon fields generated in the collisions and the quasi-particle nature of the quarks and gluons will be incorporated in the multiphase transport model that includes both initial interactions among quarks and gluons and final interactions among ordinary hadrons as well as the transition between these two phases of matters. The resulting comprehensive model will be used to study the signatures and properties of the quark-gluon plasma through the collective dynamics of produced particles, the electromagnetic radiations during the collisions, the abundance of particles that consist of heavy quarks, and the energy loss of very energetic particles produced from initial hard collisions. For nuclear reactions induced by photons at the Thomas Jefferson National Laboratory (JLAB), effective hadronic models will be used to study the production mechanism and properties of both known and missing baryon resonances.

The project has the intellectual merit of not only impacting directly the research programs at the three major nuclear physics facilities FRIB, RHIC, and JLAB in the U.S. but also contributing to the understanding of many important issues in astro- and particle physics. It also has the broader impact of providing participating young students and postdoctoral researchers a broad research experience that would prepare them well for careers in either nuclear science or other areas to continue their contributions to the scientific and technological advance in our society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our study on the properties of the strongly interacting nuclear matter produced in heavy nuclei has impacted directly the research programs at existing radioactive beams accelerators and the future Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) as well as at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN). It has also contributed to the understanding of many important issues in astro- and particle physics such as the properties of neutron stars and the properties of the quark-gluon plasma that is believed to have existed during the first microsecond after the Big Bang. It has further provided participating young students and postdoctoral researchers a broad research experience that would prepare them for careers in nuclear science and other areas to continue their contributions to the scientific and technological advance in our society.

Specifically, we have carried out a number of theoretical studies to help understand the properties of the asymmetric nuclear matter with different proton and neutron numbers as well as those of the quark-gluon plasma. Based on the novel correlations between observables of finite nuclei and nuclear matter properties, we have obtained from measured neutron skin thickness of Sn isotopes a tighter constraint on the slope of the nuclear symmetry energy, which is a measure of the binding energy difference between pure neutron matter and symmetric nuclear matter of equal proton and neutron numbers, at normal density.  This information has allowed us to better determine the transition density that separates the liquid core and inner crust of hot neutron stars and the critical temperature above which the inner crust disappears. Using a multiphase transport model that includes interactions in initial quark-gluon plasma and final hadronic matter as well as the transition between these two phases of matters, we have obtained information about the transport properties of the quark-gluon plasma from studying the collective flow and angular correlations of produced particles at the RHIC and LHC. With a two-component model that takes into account the production of quarkonia, which consist of heavy charmed and bottom quark and antiquark, from both initial hard nucleon-nucleon scattering and the regeneration in the quark-gluon plasma, we have found that their collective flow is sensitive to the production mechanism and that including their medium modifications is essential for understanding the observed suppression of their production in experiments carried out at the RHIC and LHC. Our study of dilepton (electron-positron pair) production in relativistic heavy ion collisions has indicated that the available experimental data are consistent with a broadening or shortened lifetime of vector mesons, which are the main sources of dileptons, in hot dense matter. We have also studied the relative importance of different dilepton production mechanisms in hot dense matter and pointed out the kinematic regions where production from the quark-gluon plasma is dominant. We have also shown via the coalescence or recombination model that the existence of strong diquark correlations in the quark-gluon plasma would enhance the production of baryons consisting of heavy quarks in relativistic heavy ion collisions.  Our study further shows that relativistic heavy ion collisions provide the opportunity to produce and study the properties of exotic hadrons that are made of multi-quarks instead of usual two or three quarks for normal hadrons.
